seat.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a place where you can sit, especially one in a vehicle or one from which you watch a performance, sports event etc
seat.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: I was in the back seat and Jo was driving.
People were shifting in their seats, looking uncomfortable.
seat.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: a position as an elected member of a government, or as a member of a group that makes official decisions
seat.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: He predicts that his party will gain at least 12 seats.
The Republicans hold 235 seats and the Democrats have 197.
Mr Adams is expected to keep his seat.
Labour held onto the seat with a 7% majority.
one that a party will not lose
one that another party might easily win
a seat in the National Assembly
Promotion would mean a seat on the board of directors.
seat.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: the flat part of a chair etc that you sit on
seat.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Don’t put your feet on the seat!
seat.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: the part of your trousers that you sit on
seat.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: a rip in the seat of his jeans
seat.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: a home of a rich important family in the countryside
seat.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: a place where you can sit, especially one in a vehicle or one from which you watch a performance, sports event etc
seat.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: Excuse me, is this seat free?
Patrick spotted an empty seat near the back.
Never leave bags on the back seat of a car.
He climbed into the driver's seat.
The cop in the passenger seat spun around to stare at him.
I'd prefer a window seat, please.
We managed to get ringside seats, so we had a great view of the fight.
I managed to get a fairly good seat, near the front.
We had really good seats, just in front of the stage.
A flight attendant showed them to their seats.
go back to/return to your seat
The audience clapped as he returned to his seat.
We resumed our seats for the second half of the play.
I'll save you a seat next to me.
He is an actor who will put bums on seats.
seat.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 2: a position as an elected member of a government, or as a member of a group that makes official decisions
seat.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: have/hold a seat
The Liberals now hold 292 seats in Parliament.
win a seat
The following year he won a seat on the local council.
gain a seat
At the next election the Republicans gained 12 seats in the Senate.
Labour took over fifty seats from the Conservatives.
lose a seat
She lost her seat at the last election.
keep/hold onto a seat
He is unlikely to retain his seat after next year's election.
Labour managed to hold the seat, but with a reduced majority.
contest a seat
Twenty-four candidates contested the five seats.
He ran for the seat as a Republican.
ADJECTIVES/NOUN + seat
a parliamentary seat
He and his followers won 10 of the state's 13 parliamentary seats in last month's general election.
a Senate seat
a congressional seat
a Labour/Republican etc seat
Middlesbrough is one of the safest Labour seats in the country.
a safe seat
Maidstone is considered a safe seat for the Conservatives.
a marginal seat
The party also successfully targeted marginal seats in key areas.
seat.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: if a place seats a number of people, it has enough seats for that number
seat.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to arrange for someone to sit somewhere
seat.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: the old custom of seating boys and girls on opposite sides of the classroom
seat.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: a position as a member of a government or a group that makes official decisions
seat.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Since 2005, he has held a seat on the Board of Directors.
seat.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: a position as a member of a financial market
seat.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: Foreign brokerage houses will be offered more seats on the Stock Exchange of Singapore.
